The patch was a customized 8 beat sequencer/sampler that allows the user to make their own sequences.
It included a killer Donna Summers tune as a demo as well.
Complete with beat counters and tempo control, this patch is an advanced and very clever piece of work.
There were several meters and toggles that controlled volume and whether or not the sound would play.
It also included its own keyboard for the user to compose their 8 beat masterpiece.
My favorite touch was the title and how the "III" had the colors behind it that corresponded with the different sections of the patch.
Overall, I was amazed by the work put into this patch and how well it turned out.
I am not sure if I could offer a single improvement, it's great!

Well, i do have to say this patch does look great both in presentation mode and out of it.

Right off the bat I could tell this patch a lot of thought put into it.
It a colorful, yet simplistic and organized interface that was fairly simple to use.
I was glad the author designed a presentation mode interface, because I think if I were faced with the raw patch I would have been utterly confused.
That said, a few parts of the raw patch(non presentation) were a bit disorganized, but I think that might be because they were the visual components.
The patch was an elaborate 16 beat sequencer that played a series of notes defined by the user by clicking and unclicking boxes.
I was a bit confused on how to work the patch at first, but eventually I figured it out, maybe a little blurb about directions in the future?
In addition, to that suggestion, when opening and playing the patch, I couldn't hear the sounds being played until increasing the volume almost all the way to the top/right of the slider.
This was misleading because the volume appeared to be half-way up.
The striking red outline of all the components is the first thing that catches my eye upon opening the patch; it sets the mood quite well for the song that is being played.
The sequencers have been arranged side by side with all the connections twisting about each other as they go into the message boxes.
The metronome command and toggle play both, producing the easily recognizable melody from the grand composition.
It is a stirring composition, and hearing it in bleep/bloop format is quite interesting, as if it was an NES game that the track had been taken from.
My only suggestion of improvement would be playing with the piano note synthesizer to put it into classical format.
The patch is a two-part sequencer designed to play a song with polyphony.
It uses the methods taught in class, with two "make a bleep" objects for polyphony/harmony.
The author creatively interpreted sheet music according to Max methods to try and represent a performance of a popular song, and the result is fun to play with.

In the description, the author expresses confusion as to how to represent eighth notes, which could have been achieved with relative ease by adding more steps to the counter (and consequently the sequencer), increasing the metronome tempo, and adding rests.
Moreover, a few added steps/rests at the end of the sequence would have matched the represented tune to a full bar of the song.
In general, this project is successful.
I really enjoyed this work, it was simple to understand as soon as I opened it, the colors were please to the eye and I knew exactly where to go first.
As soon as I hit the toggle I was able to recognize the song.
I liked how you did one metro in half time to even up the chords along with the lead part.
Overall very good representation of this piece through "bleeps!"
The overall look of this sequencer is very similar to the ones we did in class although there is another component which acts as a left hand and a right hand.
I like the song it makes me happy and is something I can listen to on repeat cause its fun.

A really cool song!

A suggest I have to put down is to keep decrease the size of the make a bleep command and the sound toggle.
So, a toggle sends a 1 to two different metros which then send bangs to three separate sets of counters/selects.

just starts sounding gnawing.

You did the class assignment with some added creativity.
This patch has three sequencers in it rather than the usually expected two.
The third one adds an extra element of sound by having all the tones continuously going off at the same time to produce a constant undertone.
The other two cycle through an eight-note sequencer to produce a sci-fi like melody that plays on repeat.
It sound great with the undertone going, but can feel rather stock/cliche after the first few times cycling through.

My suggestion for improvement would be either experimenting with tempo or adding in effects that can alter/distort the individual notes in a manner that the sound can change and keep pleasing listeners.
The patch looked similar to what I originally wanted to do, which was cool.

In the old days, we called some code Š—“spaghetti codeŠ— when the paths weren't clear.
One way to do that would be to break up the work into multiple select statements working off of the same counter.
That would break it up into more manageable pieces, or bars, and make it easier to maintain or modify.
However that said, I know many artists who like the organic nature of exposed wires and find them beautiful.
There's a ton of notes here making the appearance look somewhat messy, but it still follows the same design shown to us in class, and the key buttons to make it run smoothly are easily identifiable.
This patch goes starts with the toggle, goes through the metro,and then goes on to select the desired notes after counting through 48 beats.
A midi key board is included at the bottom to give a visual representation of what notes are being selected.

Well done!

Description:When activated, this patch plays a tune that is the author's original composition.
The author makes expert use of polyphony in their work.
Technical analysis:When pressed, a toggle sends a bang to a metro that counts every 300 ms. From there, a counter measures every eight counts.
If a note is to be played, a message containing the note value is sent to the "make a bleep" sub patch, and then a sine wave is generated.
Conceptual analysis:The piece is actually 4 times longer than I originally thought!
It counts through 8 beats four times, not just the same 8 beats.

The author is making a very good use of alternating selects and counts in the signal flow- meaning you can divide the piece into beats and measures by having a count that leads to a select that leads to another count that leads to another select.
The fact that the first two chords that the piece produces are very similar sounding creates a surprise moment when the last to measures sound completely different.

Although the author says in the submission that they are not a musician or composer, I think this piece shows the author has  a clear understanding about the technical/ mathematical structure that music and programming have in common.

Also, the use of color in max patches is never bad- and at firs glance it looked like the author was simply placing colored buttons at random, they actually match the pitch of the note, which is a great way to convey to the user what is being activated when a sound is played.
Improvement:The only improvement that I can see with the patch is to take a look at the select object at the furthest left.
The comment pointing to it suggests that there is a rest on the 8th beat, but the 8th beat is actually not a rest, a note is played.
Other than that there is nothing of a technical nature wrong with the patch.
One thing that the author should do, however, is be more confident in this work!
There is no need to lower expectations by suggesting in the submission that you're not a composer because you've created a wonderful composition here.
And in the patch there is a comment saying "I attempt a chord..", but in reality the author succeeded in creating that chord!
This is a great work and the author should be proud of it- there is no need to be timid about this effort.

The patch used the make a bleep with a grouping of selects, counters, and metros.
What was unique for me about this patch, was the dual melodies that could be played either together or separately without there seeming to be something lacking.
The author even enabled the user to quite easily hear each side separately or together.
In the future it isn't necessary to make duplicate metros and counters, instead make a single master time system, and the use send and receives to move timing data to the selects.
Then to make one side play and not the other, add gates between the receive and the select with a button hooked to the left inlet.
With this setup you can hit the button to allow numbers to pass to the select, and you never have to worry about one side being out of sync with the other.

Based off of the description that was written for this project, I was able to determine that this patch would have two different sections for a piece of music to be played, a lead part and a rhythm part.
Both of these parts would be able to be played separately or collectively.
The description ensures this by naming both sides and by saying that the users can do this on their own.
The way that this patch works is that it is activated by clicking on the top toggle.
The toggle then activates the two lower toggles, the two buttons and two metro objects which then activate the counters, which range from 1-32 on each side.
The counters are attached to two different sets of select objects which are numbered from 1-32.
These objects then obtain the information they need in order to play whatever note with the use of a numbered message attached to each input.
The number was attached to each input, is then attached to a number object, which shows what number it received.
This object is then attached to a subpatch that plays different midi notes based off of the individual number message it receives, it makes a sound.
Then, to toggle the sound on and off, there is an ezdac object attached to each side.
The author created a simple song with the use of 2 different set of notes.
Their sequencer branched out into two different sides, one representing the lead, the other representing the rhythm.

By including toggles on both sides as well as a top toggle, it is possible to listen to these part together or to just the listen lead or  to just the rhythm just as the description said would be possible.
Going over this patch was very easy and convenient due to the separate toggles on each side and due to the labeling of what was the lead and the rhythm that was on each side.
My only concrete suggestion is that I believe that it would be possible for the author to omit the number object that is attached to the metro objects on both sides.
It does not really serve a purpose and when I was just trying it out to affect the patch, it turned the notes into a jumble of sounds, rather than a song.

Based solely off of the description that this project has, it is very clear on what the goal is, which is to make "music" using internal synthesizers.
There was no possible way for me to misunderstand what the author was trying to accomplish.
The way that this patch works is that it is activated by clicking on the top toggle.
The toggle then activates the three metro objects and three buttons which then activate the counters, which range from 1-8 on all three sides.
The counters are attached to three different sets of select objects which are numbered from 1-8, that are also attached to 8 buttons on each branch.
These objects then obtain the information they need in order to play whatever note with the use of a numbered message attached to each input.
The number was attached to each input, is then attached to a number object, which shows what number it received.
This object is then attached to a subpatch that plays different midi notes based off of the individual number message it receives, it makes a sound.
Then, to toggle the sound on and off, there is an ezdac object attached to all three sides.
The author successfully created a sequencer that played a tune that was inspired by the Halloween season.
The way that notes were arranged really made it sound like it was a haunting tune.
The three different branches that this patch had served as a way to make chords happen.
The patch itself is really clean and I can hardly see any faults with it.
My only concrete suggestion would be that if it's possible would you be able to possibly condense your three branches down to two by maybe placing the two numbered messages on a single input?

Description:This piece produces a dissonant piece that reminds the viewer of the music from "Nightmare Before Christmas".
Technical Analysis:When the user selects a toggle, the piece activates 3 separate metros which count in sections of 8 beats.
If a note is to be played, a select sends a message containing the note value to the "make a bleep" sub patch which produces sine wave.

Conceptual analysis:I don't know if this was intentional, but the way that the buttons blink with that intense yellow along with the music reminds me of the halloween decorations that have little blinking light for eyes.
Anyway, this patch does a very efficient job a creating a haunting piece of music for the user.
It's really easy to see how everything is ordered, and how the patch works.
Suggestion:This is just a wild and crazy thing, but I noticed that the whole point of the piece is creating a dissonant, creepy, tune- and the notes seem to group together.
So, one suggestion might be that, instead of listing each individual message for the for the note, you could elevate this piece by connecting them to a random number generator instead.

That way, not only does this piece become something that is new and exciting every time someone uses is, it plays to the strengths of using a computer to make music- like the fact that computers can generate their own note values.

One way to elevate it might be to create another metro box on the second counter layer and change the speed slightly to create a different effect.

Description:This piece plays a simple 8 note tune when activated.
Technical Analysis:Then the user selects the toggle, it begins a metro with only 150 ms delay between beats.
That activates a sub patch which contains a 1 to 8 counter.
Then a select object sends a message containing the note value back to the main patch which generates a saw wave.

Conceptual analysis:The inclusion of a saw rather than a sine wave, with its gritty, mechanical tone color, plays well with the fact that the notes in the tune seems really "techno" and "computer-y".
Suggestion:In Tinapple's "make a bleep" patch, he included a message and a line object with the sine wave object that decays the tone over the length of the note.
That would be useful in this patch because when the metro is turned off, it continues to produce a tone.
It's hard to tell if you were going to a specific tune or just random notes, but if it was just random, you could include a random number generator that would greatly expand the scope of the project.

Excellent layout.
Perfect organization, nice colors, clear and big font, and nice volume bars and note selecting knobs placed throughout the patch.
The patch works by turning it "on," which then begins a piano note going at a steady tempo.
The tempe bar at the top controls the beats per minute, there are three sustain bars included each with their own volume bar, and three rows of sixteen knobs to control what notes are being played.
I absolutely love the fact that this is an interactive piece in which the user is improvising a piece of music right on the spot.
It's genuinely fun to play around with and spend time tweaking to see what type of chord progression comes out of it all.

Technical accuracy and completeness of theory and computations(a) All equations used in this project were properly described within the theory of the report.
(b) Program runs correctly and displays numbers within the ranges of expected values.
(c) Code runs, but is not explicitly verified within the body of the report.
More emphasis could be placed on why the output makes sense for given input values.
(d) Only the initial conditions chosen by the user were inputted into the code.
Further calculations and results were not described within the report.
Depth, interest, insight and scientific integrity of the study(a) The introduction clearly introduces the topic of the assignment and what concept this code is trying to convey.
It is concise and short, but provides all necessary information for an uninformed reader to follow.
(b) Since there was very little varying of parameters, the study possessed little depth and significance.
The code runs correctly, but what does the output say about the study?
About drag force?
(c) No new information is given from further computations.
(d) Conclusion vaguely covers scientific study, but does not go into detail.
Quality of the report(a) The users English is sufficient, and the read runs very smoothly and effortlessly.
Transitions are easy to distinguish and the topics flow together throughout the entire report.
(b) Though I could reproduce the calculations shown, there are very little to warrant any great understanding from simply doing so.
(c) The conclusion is somewhat vague, but conveys the major concepts and connects with the report.
(d) The report looks professional.
Graphs and tables are not simply thrown together, descriptions are placed in appropriate places, and sections flow from one to the next.

To further elaborate, the velocity would be fastest anywhere along the horizontal line at the same level of the muzzle of the cannon (1 meter above the ground).
For instance, it would be at the same magnitude of velocity on the cannon's descent at the same vertical height from the ground as the muzzle it was shot out of.
Also, speed of sound is roughly 340m/s, not 600m/s.

The patch is just as described, a magnification of athletes of different types of sports.
It works by pressing four different keys to activate four different scenes.
When the the same key trigger is pressed twice, there is a magnification bubble around the athlete to better see where exactly/what is going on.

The author created a better visual of athletes which reminds me somewhat of a video game where a button zooms/changes perspective (especially used in racing video games when changing from front to back view and zooming closer to the road).
It made me feel as though I was up close and with the athlete themselves.
I think something that could make it better would be to trigger the magnification the same way, but figure out a way for it to not start back at the beginning.
The patcher is clean and laid out very nicely.
There is a clear easy to use presentation mode.
The keys all work as stated and the buttons on presentation mode work too:) It uses 8 Videos that are modifications of 4 videos.
A double press of a key plays the video again but this time with a magnification bubble so you can see the action more clearly.
The double press was a good idea and I like it a lot.
You did need to press eight keys to see the videos, just double presses brought the modified videos up.
I see why he said it would have been nice to have the magnification and non magnification pick up at the same frame.
That is a great idea and was the only thing that could have made this project better.
I liked the videos, they were fun to watch.
Although the patcher was not completed by the author, the general construction of the patcher was easy to understand and was not too complicated in layout.
The videos are triggered through the pressing of keys and it seems as though a zoomed version of the same video is triggered by another key on the patcher.
Overall, the patcher would have been greatly executed if the author could have finished.
This problem is not so much about execution but rather the lack of time needed to execute the author's idea as he/she imagined.
If i could improve your patch, I would clean up a few unnecessary elements in the patcher.
The patch is clean and very organized.
It includes a few notes to help the reader navigate through and use the patch.
It works by linking a series of video clips to key and select objects, which then bang counters than toggle between two videos.
The concept of the patch is very intriguing, I must say.
While the intentions are kind of for naught with the current build, the idea proves to be one that could be pretty useful.
For example, what if I'm watching a video and suddenly see something that I want to zoom in on, but when I press the key again, the video starts over.
This kind of defeats the purpose of the entire patch because essentially the user either has to watch in magnified or non-magnified.
I know time was an issue for you, so this is obviously something you know would improve the patch if you could.
The patch was well-laid out and easy to follow.
When a key is pressed, a video is played and when the same key is pressed again, a magnified version of the same video is played.
There are two small technical issues, both having to do with repetition of key hits.
Once one hits the 'p' key to pause, there's not a means of unpausing without just restarting the videos.
This could be solved with a toggle for start/stop.
Also, the counters don't reset when you move to a different video, so if you return to a video you've only seen the original of after switching to a different one, it jumps to the magnification.
This can be fixed by sending a 0 to all other counters upon opening the first video.
The original intent was to have the magnified videos start at the same frame as the original videos left off.
That could have been really cool.
When I opened the patch the first thing that struck me were the bright colors of the comment boxes.
There were five videos to cycle through and mess with using various effects.
I know that to some people the intense colors could hurt their eyes, but I liked the color choice, it got my attention.
Some of the effects I couldn't get to work but overall it was fun to mess with.
The layout was neat and easy to understand even with the massive walls of text.
One thing I think that could be changed is the name of the 4th video is wrong.
I watched most of it and I don't think it's Avicii, haha.
The actual wiring of the patch is hidden, even in edit mode and I couldn't see it so I'm still curious to how this was set up.
Overall they did a great job!
I liked this project.
Although it had a TON of features and some I didn't even really see made a big difference.
However, the really cool ones were the video q,w,e,r - video effects.
That was something simple yet entertaining.
WOW.
This was a crazy complex patch.
Impressive.
I was able to press 5 different numbers and 4 different letters.
This patch played perfectly and i had no technical errors.
I loved that the patch was so colorful and caught my eye.
It makes you interested in what this patch plays and what more is it capable of doing.
The patch was very well organized.
Thank you for writing the steps on it, because I wouldn't had known what to do.
It works good.
I honestly don't know how you could improve the project.
Wow!!!
You patch is pretty complex!
and I just understand why did you name it "Perspective" I love the way that you organized preety much everything especially the different mode to show the video.
However there is a little thing in the instruction that should be change if you want to make it better, which is the instruction number 2 :  Hit escape to enter fullscreen.
When the user follow along with this instruction they will get to the full screen mode which is going to block them from the rest of the instructions.
Overall your project is super awesome!
The patch has a neat, organized presentation in which connections are clear as to where they are coming from and going into.
It is a descending hierarchy, with the main input command, key, at the top going down in rows of the particular select commands, the movie files, and then the playback setup.
I was not able to make the videos play, probably due to the fact of my Mac being bootcamped to run Windows, which is causing problems with playback, even though I have Quicktime installed.
The videos, however, were very interesting' keeping with the musical style of the previous sequencer project.
Rap is not my preferred style of music so my reaction is very neutral, but the video they are taken from is interesting in its premise.

Since the music is the primary element of the individual clips, and we're learning now how to manipulate video with sound and other input, it would be cool to see it geared towards altering the pitch and overall volume as it plays, to make the clips a little more lively and entertaining for the user.
Your patch was very easy to read and to work but the keys "G", "H", "J", "K" are all repeats of the keys before which makes the over all concept boring and like you didn't give it much thought.
I really liked the song that you picked but I also wished you picked the keys that you chose with more intention.
If you wanted to do something simple to add keys without repeating the same video I would either split up the song more or connect keys to the stop and start buttons.
Also, you never made the video full screen which would have been better just for viewing.
Upon opening, the patch was pretty simple and easy to follow.
Technically, the patch worked really well with little to no problems.
The author created a video playback based on one of his favorite songs, and it felt good for the most part.
I would say make the clips more unique as the last 3 are just repeats of the first few.
The patch looks neat and clean.
The toggle button to turn it on is at the top which makes it convenient.
There is no presentation mode, however the keys to press are clearly labeled and easy to understand.
There are four clips of a song that play alternately by pressing one of 8 keys.
The only suggestion is that the ESC toggle from large to small screen.
I liked the concept of using a repetitive song that plays in different slices of time so you can mix it yourself.
The patch was an 8-video interface with a calm setting.
Each video had a different environment meant to inspire relaxation, with a relaxing song to correspond with it.
There were 8 different windows (one for each video) as well as 8 different buttons to trigger them.
It actually did relax me!
I very much enjoyed the theme and the cool videos that went with them.
The only improvement I'd add is to connect all of the videos to one window, that way they could all play through fullscreen and there wouldn't be the problem of two videos playing at once.
Great job!

what I liked about this patch was that you could play more than one at a time.

The patch played videos triggered by touching keys on the home row after pressing the space bar to toggle it.
Being a fan of the same videos featured in the patch, I enjoyed it quite a bit!
There were a variety of wires spread all over the patch (much like was said in the description) and it was hard to see where exactly they all led to.
It works very well, though!
I had no problem figuring it all out.
It was a very cool patch overall!
My only suggestion would be to organize it, although I'm sure with the number of wires there were it would be a difficult task.
This patch has a lot of buttons and a lot of wires, several videos and fortunately some instructions.
The space bar starts and stops the videos and keys 'a' through 'l' play videos.
Counters are used as switches to jump through clips by repeatedly pressing the letter key with which the specific clip is associated.
I really like these videos, the whole genre of what they represent is so bizarre and interesting, and the jump ahead function is really gratifying.
The patch itself seems confusing and takes some time to really understand how it works but I like the creativity behind getting it to function.
I feel that whoever made this has interesting taste and the ability to do creative problem solving in their development of an idea.
Again, I couldn't full screen to work properly and that would have been super nice because these videos are so great!
Maybe next time also utilize presentation mode, it would have been cool to just enjoy what this patch does without feeling overwhelmed by being confronted with such a tangle of wires.
The patch looks very complicated with many wires and counters.
It many different connections which give it a bit of a hectic feel.
It works by connecting the each button on the home row to a counter and starting a new video about creating Japanese candy.
The videos worked in order and they was also a fullscreen option.
The cool thing about the videos was that by pressing the next key in the order of the home row you could forward the video.
Maybe for improvement try using the panel object to hid the complicated wires.
You could also encapsulate many of the connections to create sub patches and that would make the patch seem really simple.

However, if that weren't a factor, I think this is a solid project, and the only thing I noticed was that you have an extra "read" button(near the start/stop buttons) that doesn't serve much of a purpose in this particular project.
This patch didn't really sway me in feeling one was or another, though I did get a chuckle from a few of the videos.
Even though you are a beginner with max I could tell that you still pushed yourself, which is great and is definitely how you will continue to elaborate on future work.
The design and functionality is very clean and straightforward included eight keys that engage the user with the video footage.
I like that you had fun with it, I definitely got a good laugh out of the clips.
Visually it is a very strong piece as it is well organized and not intimating for the user to interact with.
Possible adding another layer of effects within the videos could have taken it to the next level.
Overall, good work!

Very simple and straight forward.
It plays eight different clips (looping) corresponding to different keys on the keyboard.
The buttons are clearly labeled, so the user knows which buttons will do something.
Before clicking any buttons to play the clip, the qmetro need to be toggled, so the video can be played.
There is also a button to return frames from the video if the qmetro is toggled off.
There are some additional bits on the side which can be controlled with sliders: rate, time, frame, volume.
It works well.
It is very minimal.
The clips were pretty iconic.
Pretty simple and fun to watch.
The mechanics of it are not particularly interesting since it only plays videos.
If there were additional things that the keys did, it would be more fun to play with.
This patcher had numerous videos that were all trigger by pressing a certain key.
With the toggle to the patch switched on, you could then press any key you like to play the videos.
I liked the patch because it was neat and very easy to follow.
There was also ease of use due to the notes that the created added into the patch which made things more understandable.
This patch could be made even better with values that could alter the videos, such as volume or fast forwarding but overall a very nice job.
Overall, the patch looks really nice, and clean.
However the video that you picked seems random to me because I barely see the connection between each video, and also the name "Humor."
I think this project can be better if you use "Loadbang" to start putting everything in fullscreen, and pick the group of videos that kinda tell the story.
The way that which the patch is described is very easy to under what it's trying to accomplish.
It is a simple eight video player that changes the video when a set of keys are pressed.
The way that which this patch works is similar to that of the patch that which we were introduced to.

There is a key object that is attached to various select objects that select the certain ASCII codes that hook up to each individual video, which are activated by a metro object, a toggle, and both a Jitter QuickTime movie object and a Jitter Window object that allows the video to play in a separate window from the patch.
In order to let the video part show itself to the user, the user must ensure that the toggle is on to show the video or else just the audio would play.
There is also a subpatch that allows the user to enter fullscreen mode and exit out of fullscreen mode by clicking the ESC key.
While using this patch, I thought it was very interesting to see what videos were going to play.
While there was some videos that corresponded to one another, there was some videos that I thought were a strange addition.
I also liked that there is a warning about turning the toggle on so that I was able to watch the videos right away.
Also, I liked how both the toggle and the stop message were both a bright red color so that it would draw more attention to it.
One suggestion that I would make in order to improve on this patch is to possibly have higher definition videos that are possibly shorter.
Some of the videos that which I saw were really rough and somewhat pixelated when I tried to watch them.

After the reading the description of this patch, I knew that the theme of this video key patch was going to be that of motorcycles.

The way that which this patch works is similar to that of the patch that which we were introduced to.

There is a key object that is attached to various select objects that select the certain ASCII codes that hook up to each individual video, which are activated by a metro object, a toggle, and both a Jitter QuickTime movie object and a Jitter Window object that allows the video to play in a separate window from the patch.
In order to let the video part show itself to the user, the user must ensure that the toggle is on to show the video or else just the audio would play.
There is also a subpatch that allows the user to enter fullscreen mode and exit out of fullscreen mode by clicking the ESC key.
There are also two keys that both stop and start the video and audio from playing.
I really enjoyed going over this patch.

The colors and labels definitely help relay information to the user on what keys need to be pressed and the videos were high definition so that they didn't look pixelated when they were played in fullscreen mode.
My only suggestion would be to write a warning about turning the toggle on.
I forgot a couple times to turn it on while I was going over this patch and I'm pretty sure that if others saw this patch, they would probably do the same.

DescriptionThis patch is an interactive pet simulator- pressing the buttons allows you to perform various activities with your virtual pet chicken.
Technical analysisWhen a key is pressed, the action causes one of several available videos to play.
Each button corresponds to a different activity.
Conceptual analysisPoints for creativity and hilariousness!
The author shows how a diverse skill set is integral to the creation of a well rounded user experience.
SuggestionWhy not take it a little further?
A couple counter objects and gate, and you could have a fully fledged game.
For example,"you can only ride the chicken after unlocking it by waking up and feeding the chicken" would add a layer of depth to this game.
I really enjoyed this work, it took the interactive aspect to a whole new level that I haven't seen in other patches.
The patch is very simple to read, the color coding helps, and it does exactly what it needs to.
The video's themselves are super creative and had me laughing a ton, I enjoyed the key prompts that were put up on the screen so you can pick what to choose next.
Overall I don't have any suggestions, the patch was perfect for the assignment criteria.

The patch read key presses and sent bangs to buttons, on to either a toggle to get the current frame, or jit.qt.movie messages.

The movies were all themed around musical guests on Jimmy Kimmel's show, but I felt as though playing more of the act than the first 10 - 20 secs would have made for a stronger execution of the theme.
For some reason on my computer Max struggled with the Iggy Azalea clip (topped at ~8fps) but had no trouble with the other 4 (average ~30fps).
As far as patching goes, you could accomplish the play/pause function using a single key if you hooked the select object to a toggle and from there to a message of "rate $1".
The toggle would then send a value of either 0 or 1 every time you pressed the key, eliminating the need for unique start/stop keys.
Additionally you do not need to have different sel objects for each key, you can add those all to a single sel with each key listed.
This patch is very clean and organized and well done.

DescriptionThis patch plays a video when the asdfghjk keys are pressed.
Technical analysisThe key object waits for a key press which triggers a read message with the video file name to be loaded into the jit window.
Conceptual analysisOverall, this patch utilizes a simplistic design to deliver a "low brow chuckle".
It's really easy to see how it works, the labels make the author's intent clear: laugh.
SuggestionMy only suggestion would be to move the video window higher in the patch, on a small screen it is difficult to see the buttons and the video at the same time.
Other than that, everything looks very good.
This patch looks clean and has the basic setup for a video key patch.
It works too, and I found that the videos that were triggered were interesting.
Overall though this patch gets the job done and does it right.
When you go into presentation mode, it's very pleasing to the eye, and very clear in what you're supposed to do.
You just hit a key to play a certain video.
The videos were all pretty funny, especially the last one with Sir Ben Kingsley swearing like a sailor.
It was nicely done, and very well constructed, and it works how the creator wanted to.
I really can't think of anything that might need to be improved on.
The first thing I noticed when I opened your patcher was the Halloween theme and how you were able to make it look Halloween like.
The videos were fun to watch.
I had to turn on your metro, you could have rigged it to the key object to turn on with any key stroke.
Well, you certainly nailed your intended theme!
The Nightmare Before Christmas is a great watch, so I enjoyed seeing this.
However, the videos you chose were really long and I found myself getting kind of bored and tired of waiting for them to end.
I know this wasn't really taught to us, but I think setting it up so the videos don't play back from the beginning every time the key is pressed would really improve the work.
Visually, the patch is very fun to look at.
It was a wise and creative move to recolor the objects - it really adds to the dynamic and makes the halloween theme decidedly apparent.
A suggestion would be to include more videos.
The assignment called for at least 8 keys, and you only used three.
This patch is designed to play different parts/musical numbers from the movie "The Nightmare Before Christmas" upon pressing three different keys.
Technically, it works very similarly to the example patch from class.
Conceptually, the patch is evocative of the spirit of Halloween, but is otherwise too simple to be really engaging.
The author might improve this work by including more clips mapped to more keys, or by sticking to a more cohesive and specific theme.
DescriptionThis patch plays a couple pieces from Tim Burton's "Nightmare Before Christmas" when the b , d , and l keys are pressed.
Technical ananysisThe key object waits for a key press, if b, d, or l are pressed, then a corresponding video is loaded into the jit player.
Conceptual analysisThe author makes a good use of the ability to customize the look of the patch.
Coloring the background black, and the other objects yellow and orange makes the whole patch feel like "halloween".
I especially enjoyed to SuggestionFor queuing the metro automatically, you can use the loadbang object, that way the user doesn't have to do it themselves.

Also, don't be afraid to really play with the patches that Tinapple gives us in class- I noticed that the button attached to the jit.qt.movie object that shows how you can display each frame with a bang, didn't really add to the experience of this patch.
At first glance I can't see the video window without scrolling to the bottom of the patch, it may be better if you make that one of the first visible things.
Also, consider using the [loadbang] object to open the metro toggle and the start button.
I like the creative effort you put into resizing the buttons and aligning the patch cords, it makes it look nice.
You might want to try adding a [panel] object to hide some of those things, though.
I was surprised to see so many clips in such a small file size, I like that you used short lengths of footage.
It saved on the download time, this is something I disregarded completely.
Good work!
The patch plays several short video clips upon pressing different keys.
Technically, it is an expanded version of the patch from class.
Conceptually, it's very simple, and seemingly designed more for fun than for any other artistic purpose; it's function is pretty similar to that of a soundboard.
The author might improve this work by cranking up the volume on some of these clips, as the source material seems to be a bit quiet.
This patch is quite colorful--the bang messages have many layers of different colors--and conceived in the prescribed demo structure.

The program works by taking the input of the user, in this case pressing a letter on the keyboard, and seeing as it triggers a video clip to play through the patch; the user also has the capability of watching the clip in fullscreen mode and can leave it with a press of the Escape key.
Not to be biased, but Clint Eastwood is one of my all-time favorite actors, so the viewing of his many memorable, insanely famous quotes was quite entertaining.
If you could implement all the video manipulating commands we were just taught to control speed, volume, and maybe even pitch, that would be a great enhancement.
I enjoyed the cartoons in the patch.

What the author of the patch did was quite simple, making video clips play with certain keys.

After reading the description for this patch, I thought that it was going to be interesting that this patch was going to be a game in order to find out the correct order of the entire overall video.
The way that which this patch works is similar to that of the patch that which we were introduced to.

There is a key object that is attached to various select objects that select the certain ASCII codes that hook up to each individual video, which are activated by a metro object, a toggle, and both a Jitter QuickTime movie object and a Jitter Window object that allows the video to play in a separate window from the patch.
In order to let the video part show itself to the user, the user must ensure that the toggle is on to show the video or else just the audio would play.
There is also a subpatch that allows the user to enter fullscreen mode and exit out of fullscreen mode by clicking the ESC key.
Also, the spacebar stops the video from looping.

Once again, I had fun trying to figure out what the order was, the question marks that masked what the letter for the word was very creative and I thought that it was pretty cool that if I pressed the wrong keys that the letters that I already had up would reset.
It made me very cautious as to which key to press.
I also liked how the instructions and even the size of the toggle were large so that the user would automatically know what to do.
My only suggestion would be to add a button that starts the loop back up again, like how the space bar stops the loop.
It was very inconvenient that I would have to press the start message to start it back up again instead of just pressing a key.
This was a really cool patch.

However, if your next guess is unsuccessful, all question marks re-appear.

It was a fun little game nonetheless.

Overall, there is a key object that is attached to various select objects that select the certain groups of ASCII codes that hook up to each individual video, which are activated by a metro object, a toggle, and both a Jitter QuickTime movie object and a Jitter Window object that allows the video to play in a separate window from the patch.

DescriptionThis patch allows the user to preview eight MTV Hot Videos with the 1-8 keys on the keyboard.
Technical analysisWhen the user presses a key, it loads a corresponding video into the jit video player- pressing the space bar sends the stop message.
Conceptual analysisYes!
This author expertly organizes the patch into a very user friendly and well designed experience.
I can't tell you how much scrolling was necessary for other projects because they left the "vertical" nature of Max intact.

SuggestionThere is nothing wrong with the patch, but I think the author is able to take this piece even further, aesthetically.
For example, you could use the fpic object to include a picture of the album cover that the songs are from, and arrange it similar to cover flow on iTunes.
For this format, the possibilities are almost endless.

DescriptionThis patch plays a clip from an anime when the "g" key is pressed.
Technical analysisThe key object listens for a key press, and when the "g" key is pressed, begins playing a video clip.
Conceptual analysisThis patch is very simple, there is not a lot of concept behind this execution, unless I'm completely missing the significance of the anime clip, or something.
SuggestionThis patch is a good jumping off point for this project.
