The team is trying to achieve a modern short story.
In that, I mean formats that are common in today's communications.
The Research and Inspiration section of the proposal is the strongest and most thought through section.
It shows the background they have based their premise on and where they want to take their work, citing references for both.
This section also gives a valid argument for the choice of a short story format for the assignment.
The outline needs some work.
This section does not sound interesting or intriguing at all.
The sections on each side, the summary and research and inspiration, make this work different.
The outline however makes it sound like so many short stories already on the market.
The team will have a challenge making a short story format entice and pull in the reader yet be different and modern at the same time.
A short story has limited time and space to make all this work.
Per Edgar Allan Poe's theory of singularity, a work should be readable in 30 minutes to 2 hours at the most.
With this thought in mind, the team has a challenge in front of them.
The team aims to achieve a reader based outcome story for their project.
The greatest strength of this proposal is the outline, it takes you quickly and easily through the concept.
The summary is also done well by giving a basis, "a fan-fiction story," and an explanation while the outline builds on this.
The research and inspiration needs work.
It is confusing and nothing but quotes, barely explaining why the works are used.
The confusion comes from the use of "Jaws" instead of what I believe should be Ludovician.
Another gap that needs filling is a work cited list, there is none.
The challenge I see with the execution will be all the links, videos and pictures.
Making sure the links work properly and if using videos and pictures from other sources, making sure there is no copyright and citing them properly.
This project attempts to change the history of one person in a format unstated.
The proposal is thorough and well thought out with great detail and research.
This proposal was written by one person about one person.
The division of labor indicates a group and if this is so then this proposal does not meet the guidelines of the assignment.
There is also no work cited listed.
There is a lot of time to cover in this proposal and even using the group it would be a monumental task but by oneself I do not see it being completed in time.
This group will achieve a new and exciting format of the book, they hope.
This proposal is well written as a whole, thoroughly researched and well planned.
The sections move smoothly from one to the next building on the idea stated in the summary.
The only thing I see missing is a work cited list.
TIme is going to be an issue with these gentlemen.
With what they are describing there will be a lot of links between the three storylines that need to be verified and perfected.
A choose-you-own-adventure type of story.
The reader can choose to read all, some, or one of the narratives.
Lots of detail.
Almost too much, but the point/idea gets across well.
The research/inspiration section for the fathers' POV does not list research materials outside of the author's personal experiences.
It also does not tell us what format/type of narrative will be used.
Only the section about the daughter tells us how the story will be a future book.
No works referenced section.
Writing, editing, and compiling three different stories, each at least 2k words, then putting all of them together in Twine by the deadline.
A non-linear progression of the main character time traveling to "fix" his live.
Thorough outline of the story, good examples of research/inspiration.
Division of labour needs to be thought through.
It sounds like the other members of the group either were not consulted or were unavailable for collaboration prior to the submission deadline.
No works referenced section.
Communicating with the other group members and collaborating on a project they were not initially part of.
Engage the reader in the story using a quiz-like approach.
This sounds so fun.
I like choose your own adventure stories and love the quizzes on BuzzFeed and it sounds like this is the best of both.
Use of second person POV adds to the uniqueness.
Fantastic arguments in the inspiration/research section, very clean.
The Summary and the first section of the Outline are repetitive.
Building 8 scenarios for each section of the story, creating macros, etc, might be time consuming.
The reader will be able to see into the lives of two men who have different home lives.
We will be able to see their similarities, differences, and how each wants what the other has.
I like the convergent/divergent storyline idea, where the characters intersect and break apart again, giving the reader a broader view of the world being created in the story.
Good use of non-traditional/digital inspirations, especially since this is a "future" book.
Works referenced (in MLA format) section missing, some grammar and punctuation errors make the proposal confusing at times.
While I love the idea for the potential for endless parallel stories (the barista, co-workers, etc) it could get bogged down if too many secondary characters get their own stories.
The group seems to be putting together a story that the reader decides and narrates himself.
It seems like the group has an awesome "idea" and they know exactly how they are going to tackle writing their rough draft of the assignment.
I loved how they already know the different characters that the readers will choose from and that their final project has a purpose:  to answer the question "What kind of nerd are you?"
It seems as though quite a bit of work has been done already, even in putting together the proposal.
I'm eager to read this group's final project!
I think that this group has a great "idea", but I see it being difficult to carry out.
It seems that the purpose is for the reader to become the narrator, which I can't imagine tackling.
It seems like a ton of work and I just hope that this group knows the amount of work that they've signed themselves up for.
Other than that, it seems like a solid proposal and that the workload is divvied up fairly.
Like I said above, I just hope that this group has enough time to get the project done.
It seems like they chose a quite an intense way to tell their story and that they have a similarly intense workload ahead.
I just hope that they have enough time to accomplish their narrative and do it well!
It seems as though this group will be writing a fictional story of two men who live parallel to one another and fantasize about the life choices of the other.
It seems like a great idea that can easily hit the 2000 word count requirement!
It seems like the basic storyline has been decided and this group knows exactly how they're going to tell their story.
I love their story idea and feel like they'll be able to blow through this assignment fairly quickly while still having to finish "The Raw Shark Texts" this week.
They were smart in choosing their topic and feel like they will actually be able to enjoy writing this paper!
It doesn't seem like this group needs much critique.
They were thoughtful in putting together their proposal, which will make writing their story simple.
They put in the work on the front end so they will be able write freely this week and will easily be able to put together a story that hits the 2000 word count requirement.
If anything, I think that their biggest struggle will be that two different group me members are writing the two stories of the two men separately.
It would probably turn out more perfectly if one group member wrote the story of both men so the writing style stayed the same and the stories made sense "together".
I think that the fact that they've decided to complete the assignment separately will give them the most trouble.
As stated above, I feel like the fact that two different people writing the two stories of the two men will give them the most trouble.

I feel like they should either write the stories together (like via FaceTime or Skype) so they can brainstorm and work through it together, or that only one group member should write the story lines of both men and then the other group members work through the rough draft and make changes.
I feel that the stories will make more sense and flow so much better if only one group member actually writes the rough drafts of them.
No matter what way you end up doing this, I wish you guys luck and am eager to read your final assignment!
It seems as though this group is aiming to writing a fan fiction piece based on a required text for the class "The Raw Shark Texts" through the eyes of Eric Sanderson's girlfriend Clio Ames.
The reader of the project will chose Clio's path through the story by making decisions for her by having a choice of links throughout the final project.
It seems as though this group has a solid plan of action and has divided the work fairly amongst the group members.
I feel like after reading the other groups' proposals, this one seems the least creative to me.
The proposal isn't as thorough as the rest of the groups' proposals and I have a feeling that it will be hard for this group to hit the 2000 word count requirement.
I feel like this group didn't put in as much time on the front end of this assignment as the other groups and will struggle through the assignment this week as a result.
I also think that it will be a struggle to "write the paper together" as it seems they plan on doing.
This group has their work cut out for them this week and I only wish them luck!
As stated above, I worry that this group will have a hard time with their project this week.
I feel like because they've decided to just "write the story together", it won't flow nicely and the different group members' writing styles will clash.
I feel like their grade will suffer in the end because they've chosen to complete the project in this fashion.
It seems as though this group is writing a story that the reader will navigate through, that the reader will chose the outcome of the story himself.

It seems as though this group sufficiently thought through this assignment, that they've divided the work fairly amongst the group members and they've decided on the readers' story options within their text.
This will make writing their final assignment much so much easier than if they hadn't already done this!
I feel like it may be a challenge for this group to hit the 2000 word count requirement.
They only have a basic outline of their story, whereas some of the other groups have been much more detailed in how their stories will develop.
Like I said above, I feel like this group needs to come up with more detailed outline before they begin to write their portion of the assignment separately.
It will only help them to all stay on track and for their final assignment submission to flow smoothly.
I feel like they will be able to write the assignment so much more quickly and smoothly if they do this first.

The outcome will consist of unifying two strangers with one single thought at the end, further implying that two completely different men can have the same worries, regrets, and dissatisfactions within their very different lives.
Hopefully, this outcome will also be both surprising and rewarding to the reader, who will feel that there has been a bigger message within the two stories.
This is a unique idea, and its biggest strength is in its very clear outline.
Having that much detail will make the project much easier to pull off.
I wouldn't say there are any gaps, but I wonder if Andrew's subplot story-writing is really necessary considering the bulk of the stories will be relatively simple.
Constructing the story sounds like the most difficult part, and hopefully will be done as a team rather than left up to one person.
This is where the outline will need further definition.
I'm not entirely sure what the outcome is supposed to be, except that this will be a new experimental type of book.
I'm guessing the achievement will lie in entertaining and surprising the reader, and I think that's definitely going to happen if executed well.
The amount of inspiration and research going into the project--and the texts that were chosen--are really great.
Leaping off of these will surely result in something fantastic.
The outline seems very, very bare.

And while it does indicate a different type of book, perhaps something profoundly minimal, I still wonder if the outline is truly descriptive enough to hold the process together if artist's block comes.
Making this on Twine seems like a big challenge, as it can't just be a point and click thing, like flipping pages on a book.
There needs to be some sort of design, a maze, or course that the book follows.
This project will create a quiz/game environment where the reader is addressed directly and led through a series of questions.
Depending on their answers, the reader will then learn what actor/book character they are.
The "interruptible" aspect of the book and its choices lends to its uniqueness, making it seem less like an online quiz and more like a new sort of personality test.
Because this should still be considered a book, I feel that it's lacking a real outline.
Will the questions involve scenes, dialogue, story structure of any kind?
What exactly makes this a book?
This of course could be fleshed out in the final project, but as of right now, I don't quite see it.
My answer for 3 kind of fits with this too.
While the execution will be based more on sight and text, seamless pages, and the like, I do think it might miss the mark for a "future book" project.
Through the epistolary format--albeit futuristic via email--the book will tell a story about Adam finally getting the nerve to ask for a bartender's number.
The experience will hopefully be new, engaging, and fun for the reader.
The basic idea for this is really inventive, and I think it'll be fun to see it all pan out.
Using research about email communication can really make this unique, yet extremely relatable.
I feel like the general outline lacks beginning, middle, and end.
The plot will mostly likely flesh itself out as the story is written, but right now I don't see a real ending to the story in the proposal, or any twists and turns.
I think this could easily become very basic, point and click, turn the page sort of narration.
As long as you keep it interesting, the idea of spying on someone's email can keep a reader engaged, but you run the risk of losing the reader through repetition.
This team wants the reader to experience a convergence of time between two stories.
They want the reader to read two stories of two men who lead very different lives, yet somehow still manage to have the same experiences.
I think that the team has thoroughly thought their sources through; they have a firm grasp on the texts they want to draw upon and they are looking to achieve something akin to the mentioned texts.
In addition, these sources are dynamic, and touch on a wide array of information.
Social media as a source is also an interesting thought, and can certainly be utilized in the plot.
Also, two simultaneous stories seems to be an interesting way to draw the reader in to the story itself.
I think that the proposal was very well.
There was a clear outline demonstrating what exactly the group tends to accomplish, as well as a very detailed list of sources that the team intends to draw from.
Additionally, it appears that the group has worked very well together and that they are in clear agreement of the division of work.
The only problem I see is the story not being able to become something; it seems to me that, after having read the outline, I have already read the story itself.
I feel like the two men need to have more of a connection, or an experience that makes them realize that their lives are intertwined.
It would even be interesting if they somehow switched lives (although that would be a little too complex, I think).
Regardless, I just think that, the two stories need to be more connected than simply showing the similarities in the two men and their lives.
Something needs to be significant in this connection, and the men need to realize what that significance is.
Otherwise, there won't seem to be an importance in the story.
The team wants to write a fanfiction of The Raw Shark Texts.
This fanfiction will use twine to manipulate the events of the story, as well as the character's choices.
The reader will be in control of these happenings.
I think that, in relation to twine, this is a great idea.
Using a story that many people can relate to and enjoy, and re-creating it so that the reader may decide the fate of the characters, seems very fitting indeed.

It seems as if, were such a program to exist for any book - say, Harry Potter or The Hunger Games, millions of people would flock to the program in order to re-create their favorite stories to be the way they want them.
This being said, I think that allowing the reader to re-create the love story between Eric and Clio is a strength and using twine is definitely the way to do it.
I think this proposal meets the standards set forth by the instructor.
The only other thing I believe there would be to do would be to write the actual story.
There are only so many ways you can explain that you are going to write a fan-fiction without simply writing it.
I also think that the team explained in great detail their sources and their reasons behind using the sources, as well as explaining the division of work.
I think the hardest part of putting this story together will be embodying the characters of Clio and Eric.
As a fanfiction, the story will have to stick to the character's personalities in a sense, to stay true to the original story.
In essence, fanfictions are not new, and have existed for a very long time.
Thus, the only thing that will be setting this fan-fiction apart from regular fan-fictions is twine, or the method in which you are executing the story.

Therefore, I think it is necessary to keep this in mind when creating the story, so that you may use events and technologies in your twine story that will help make this fanfiction jump out as being 'futuristic'.
This group is wanting to achieve a futuristic experience for the reader.
They are hoping for the reader to be a 'detective' almost, stringing together the clues of the multidimensional "Voices".
I think the proposal was strong in that it gave a very strong summary of what the goal / intention for the project.
I also think that the group has a very clear understanding of their sources and the ways in which they want to draw from their sources.
The reasoning behind the sources was very concrete and well-explained, and it seems as if the sources will be a good source of inspiration to the group.

In addition, I would just like to say that I was amused at the description in the division of work section, and I think it is very respectable that two of the group members worked so hard to construct this project.
The only thing that I believe needs to be more constructed is the outline; right now it is rather vague and I am honestly extremely confused it.
I understand that this is what is supposed to be, but I would finalize things such as "Some characters; Some stories; speed is choice of writer."

I understand that you need these things to be vague and that you can't give away the story, but I think that making fragmented phrases into sentences would really help with allowing the reader to understand the general intention of the story.
I think that if the group members figure out all of the details to their plot, the story will come together nicely.
This type of story is perfect for twine and I think that if everything can be pieced together in a way that makes sense, this will be a great example of a futuristic book.
The group appears to trying to emulate modern communication whilst telling a story.
The strengths lie in that the group already has a very good idea of what they want to write, how they want to write, and what sorts of inspirations they're looking forwards while writing the story.
The idea of using a "reply" button in order to continue the story is particularly brilliant.
I honestly do not see any major flaws in this proposal.
The main challenge will probably be managing to be both expository in nature while not making it seem unnatural for the main characters to be communicating in such a fashion.
However, I do not see many major foreseeable issues with this group.
It aims to use the publishing program in order to both reminiscence about the past while also contemplating the future.
The story seems very personal, while also well thought in terms of story arc and character.
The proposal is VERY lopsided in terms of labor, as it more or less requires the entire story to be written by a singular person.
It really ought to be more inclusive, or at least have all the members writing about their personal past school experiences rather than just focusing on just one person's.
I have to wonder if this proposal was written with any group consensus in mind.
Since the workload hasn't been decided on yet, this can become a serious issue if one member is late on their part (be it the writing, editing, learning how to use the Twine program, etc.)
The group appears to be writing several stories that converge and diverge at various points in order to create a unique reading experience.
It's great the the inspirations for the project step outside of the box, particularly in regards to social media and film.
As the final project is meant to step beyond the book, as it were, using these influences to create something unique is very smart.

Smaller details--such what the men do for their individual jobs, the specific steps they take to part their facade in place--do seem to be missing, especially in regards to any research that might be necessary to complete this project.
However, it is hardly necessary to have all the details ironed out at this part, so it's simply a minor gap in the grand scheme of things.
The biggest for this group will probably be the coding necessary to tell a multi-linear story in the Twine program.
The group seems to anticipating this with their workload, however, so hopefully it won't be a challenge at all.
The group appears to be interweaving interactivity, sounds, visuals, and literature in order to tell a griping story about the mind.
The strengths of this group are clearly in their organization and planning.
The proposal is very detailed and all the members seem to have a grasp on what is needed from all them to accomplish this goal.
It's minor, but the DSM V would much more better for research than the DSM IV, due to some significant changes made between editions.
Other than that, there's little to criticize about this project proposal.
The greatest challenge this group has will undoubtedly be research.
Mental disorders often overlap and are difficult to write about--not everyone with the same mental disorder experiences the symptoms in the same way, for example.
Best of luck to this group nonetheless.

It seems that the idea behind this project proposal is to allow a reader to follow two characters who work in the same office as they experience certain events that occur during one day in their lives.

The reader will have the option to jump back and forth between the characters and then be confronted with a choice as to whether to sympathize with the married man who longs to be single or to sympathize with the single man who longs to be married.
For the ending, however, it is not clear in the proposal what common thought the two men will have.
This may, in fact, be left up to the reader to decide.
This story is fairly ambitious, but could come off well if the navigational links are effective.
It seems to satisfy the requirement for Š—“a storyŠ— and the references appear to be relevant.
Overall, the objectives for content (four major sections) have been satisfied.
In the final version, there should be some detail about the actual linking strategy that will be employed in Twine to be able to pull this off.
There seems to be a large number of probable branch (and perhaps conditional) points in the story, so the authors need to be very careful how they develop the links and the story navigation.
If not careful, there is some potential for the reader to be left stranded, with no convenient way to return to his desired point in the story.
Also, the final should include the full citations for the references.
The most significant challenge will be to make all this work as planned in Twine, particularly if there is a plan to include additional multimedia features such as images, audio, or video).

This project will use the hyper-linking features in Twine to create a story in which readers can choose different pathways in learning more about a book that becomes a model for all other books and essentially changes the way books are written.
This story is very ambitious, but will be very interesting as long as the numerous links that are proposed are designed effectively and if the navigational links are logical.
It seems to satisfy the requirement for Š—“a storyŠ— and the references are relevant to the goals of the project.
Overall, the objectives for content (four major sections) have been satisfied.

Considering the numbers of links, decision points that seem to be planned for this project, the final version should provide some additional detail about the various branches readers will be able to take.
As in any non-trivial Twine story, the authors should to be very careful how they develop the links and the story navigation so the reader does not get caught at dead ends.
Also, the final should include the full citations for the references.
The most significant challenge will be to make all this work as intended in Twine, particularly if there is a plan to include additional multimedia features such as images, audio, or video).

The intent is of this project is to re-create part of the story in Š—“The Raw Shark TextsŠ— in Twine by allowing the reader to be Clio Aames, a character very important to Eric Sanderson, the primary protagonist in the book.
The linking and other multi-media capabilities in Twine will also be used to enhance the storyŠ—Ès effectiveness.
The eventual planned outcome of the story will either be escape from the Shark (the Ludovician) or permanent entrapment.
This is a very good idea for a story to be developed in Twine.

It is quite ambitious, but if the storyline can be developed as outlined in this proposal, and if the audio and video enhancements can be successfully implemented, this story should be a very interesting interactive experience for the reader.

The proposal satisfies the requirement for Š—“a story,Š— the objectives for content (four major sections) have been satisfied, and the references mentioned in the Š—“Research and InspirationŠ— section are appropriate (Š—“Jaws,Š— Š—“Frankenstein,Š— and Š—“The Old Man and the SeaŠ—).
In the final version, there should be some detail about the actual linking strategy that will be employed in Twine to be able to pull this off.
There seems to be a large number of probable branch (and perhaps conditional) points in the story, so the authors need to be very careful how they develop the links and the story navigation.
If not careful, there is some potential for the reader to be left stranded, with no convenient way to return to his desired point in the story.
Also, the final should include the full citations for the references.
The most significant challenge will be to make all this work as planned in Twine, particularly if there is a plan to include additional multimedia features such as images, audio, or video).

The idea fueling this proposed story seems to be the creation of a different kind of story Š—– one that introduces both animate and inanimate Š—“voicesŠ— to the reader, and to use the hyperlinking and some of the graphical features of Twine to develop an interactive scenario that allows for branching and exposure to various natural features of our physical environment.
An actual end-point, or resolution for the reader is not evident in the proposal.

In terms of formatting, this proposal meets the stated objective for content (four major sections), and it is a plus that the references have been fully cited, but other aspects have not yet been entirely thought through, at least as indicated so far (see next critique section).
The story as described and outlined so far is nebulous and needs to be fleshed out and explained more in the Final Proposal.
It is not yet clear what the various Twine links will do for (or to) the reader, and the Š—…voicesŠ—È that are mentioned should be further clarified.
Also, what is the intended end state for the reader?
Will there be critical choices to be made?
Is there some sort of moral to the story at the end?
There should also be some clarification and discussion about the actual linking strategy to be used in Twine and some additional information about the types of images that may be incorporated.
(BTW, I know that this group was somehow short changed in that there were only two contributing members -- perhaps this may be rectified for the remaining iterations of the project).

Perhaps the most significant challenges will be to work out all of the planned Twine links so they make sense and to make all of this work in Twine without including untended branches to the story and dead-end links, from which the reader has no place to go.
I love the idea of interlinking the story and having clio possibly fail in the attempt to evade and escape the Ludovician.
You have a nice chunk of inspiration and research to go off of.
I like the idea of taking Raw Shark Text and expanding it into an interactive game so to speak utilizing pieces of pop culture along the way.
I think the biggest strength is the interlinking idea.
The group seems to have a good grasp of how to employ Twine in a way that is interesting and difficult but should offer a lot of opportunity for readability and enjoyment for the readers.
I think that the level of inspiration and research the group has is their strongest aspect as they are taking from man sources and are using very specific points.
The group has more of an interactive game than anything else and it seems to be very well planned.
I think the biggest obstacle is the division of labor.
My chief concern is that the beginning of the story and the middle/end might suffer from a large tonal shift or change in written voice if it is skipping writers a lot.
I would be sure to really collaborate a lot so the voice is meshed between everyone and isn't obviously different writers.
I think the biggest challenge for your group and probably for many groups will be piecing it all together inside of Twine.
Considering the inter-linking and issues of running int Clio not being able to escape and having to restart, etc.
I think that the Twine installation will be your most cumbersome task.
I would focus on completing the story aspect quickly so you can focus on solidifying and bugs that will be in your twine story on
To create the hypothetical story of the future of a fictitious family.
I really like the idea of the various outcomes this families life can play and it really prompts the reader to go back and see how different every family might have been.
I think the biggest strength for this group is the planning it already has set in motion and the various stories that are to be written.
By collaborating on the general idea but venturing off into ones own stories you completely make the characters unique with their own voices, perceptions and ideas.
Everyone being inspired by different sources and texts and everyone having a totally unique writing style should create a really well rounded story as a whole in the end.
I think one of the biggest concern you need to have is a lack of consistency in character voices throughout the story.
For instance the Wife/Mother story will have the father.
But if the Husband/Father is a completely different character in the Wife's story than how he is perceived by the reader in the Husband/Father story, then you run into a continuity issue.
The reader if first reading the Husband/Father story and going back to reading the wife/mother will have a differing opinion about her going in.
She will feel dishonest to him as he already previously met her in the father/husband story.
I would maybe think about once the rough drafts of each story are finished, have each other read over them and see how you can make the characters seem the same throughout.
The biggest issue for your group that I can see is not in the building of the story into Twine, that aspect will be simplistic with few hyperlinks.
I think the biggest issue for your group will be in creating a consistent narrative across the three stories will keeping each one unique.
I like the huge amount of pop culture utilized in your project.
I think this is a fun idea that prompts the reader to go back again and again trying every option to see all the possibilities.
The biggest strength for this group is probably its pre existing knowledge of all the source material.
Obviously you are all fans of Harry Potter and Dr. Who for instance and have a wealth of knowledge of those stories as a result.
This will help you complete the task of figuring out what questions the narrator might ask and how to answer them to create an honest assessment of what kind of a nerd would like Harry Potter, etc.
I would make sure that the project does not amount to nothing more than a buzzfeed quiz.
There are a lot of "What kind of Wine Drinker Are you?"
type quizzes online and this project needs something bigger to set itself apart from that.
I think the most significant challenge for this team concerns their ability to create something that is still mysterious and interesting to the reader.
It will be a really fun and exciting project if completed with the right amount of passion that I think this group is willing to put into it.
What the person who wrote this proposal is aiming to achieve is the creation of a semi-biographical work of fiction.
It will examine the idea of being able to advise younger versions of oneself with the knowledge gained with age.
I think the concept is a good one and could certainly be turned into quite an interesting story.
The progression of the story and its ultimate effect seem to be fairly thoroughly thought through.
The author appears to be quite certain of his goal.
There are still a lot of blanks to be filled in as to how this story will utilize the technology of the program Twine in its storytelling effort.
Perhaps if the reader does not have to experience the different time jumps in a particular order it would make it even more interesting.
Really playing up reader interactivity should be one of the goals.
Finally, the author may want to rethink writing a section of the story for every single grade of their schooling.
Maybe sticking to the most significant years or experiences over this time period.
It seems as though it would get a bit laborious reading through seventeen panels of significant length for each grade when the character has only advanced a single year.
If the panels are shorter this might work, but then the author would have a tougher time ensuring the emotional development of the story.
The author seems to have written this proposal entirely on his own with essentially no initial collaboration or discussion with his group.
His idea is also not really structured in such a way that it allows his other group members to participate in it's creation.
While this would make a good individual project, it does not seem very well thought out for a group format.
The intended outcome of the project is to create a multilinear story that utilizes the technology of Twine to allow a highly interactive experience for the reader.
The plan to incorporate a multitude of options to jump to various points in the story.
They have a very interesting idea that seams to be inspired, in part, by the premise of the class.
The subject matter is that of the creation of a future book that changes literature forever.

The seems to have a well thought out plot that is reminiscent of the layer story of Abrams & Dorst's S. Their goal to allow a range of interactive freedom to the reader can create a unique experience where a reader could return to the story multiple times and have a different experience by making different choices.
The biggest gaps I can see come merely with the need to iron out the details of the structure.
How and where will the links be positioned to jump to various parts of the story and what will be the logic for such jumps?
Even if the reader chooses to jump all over the story, some sort of flow must be maintained or the story will appear as nothing more than a random and chopping string of non-sequential events.
Again, the structure needs to be solidified.
The goal can't just be for the "largest possible number of intersections between narratives" if those intersections aren't carefully planned and make sense to the reader.
Allowing the reader freedom to guide their own interaction with the story is a great idea.
However, if enough care isn't given to the sense of where the jumps and intersections are placed, the story could just become a jumbled mess.
There is no proposal attached to this assignment.
Therefore, I can not critique the proposal for this group.

This team intends to tell a third person linear fiction story.
At least on that begins as third person, but experiments with other POVs and tenses as it progresses.
The story is an interesting one that employs elements of sci-fi and fantasy.
It appears as though it will be laid out in the form of a sort of story game, where the reader can actually impact the outcome of the story by their choice.
This structure is similar to the old "Find-Your-Fate" books, where the reader was given a choice of various pages to which they could turn in order to make corresponding decisions in the story.
It should be interesting to see how it comes out.
The interactivity of the story is part of what will draw the reader in, but it must be done in a way that does not derail the story at every turn.
The story must be able to be followed seamlessly, even through these transitions.
Additionally, switching POV and tense is something that shouldn't just be done at random, or it could confuse the reader.
It should be purposeful and warranted, based upon the events of the story.
Experimenting with multiple forms of storytelling can either add or detract from a story, depending upon how it is done.
It seems as though this team is on the right track.
They just need to do several run throughs and a lot of testing to make sure their structure is solid.
Putting out this kind of effort is useless if the end product is too hard for the reader to navigate.
A highly interactive piece like this needs to be constructed very carefully.
I believe the purpose of this project is to amuse the reader by comparing them to a specific "book or TV character" based on their choices as they progress through the narrative.
The team aims to somewhat mimic the format of the old "Choose Your Own Adventure" books, allowing readers to interact with the story by making decisions about how they will proceed.
One strength is the way the team has chosen to use Twine's interactive hyperlinks.
Readers must decide on plot direction, using a "responsive format" which I think will give the endeavor a kind of fun-psychological-quiz experience.
The team seems to have polished their list of character options (e.g.
Bilbo Baggins, Tony Stark, Hook, etc.
); I think these different genres of characters do speak to different personalities in general.
I'm curious about what the other "scenes" will be.
So far I only know of the "digging a hole" bit.
The rest of the story could be considered a gap that needs filling, but I'm confident that the team will work on this.
With different choices different lines of narrative may need to be written in order to support the different possibilities.
If the team is not careful, this fun work could become very labor-intensive.
This team seems to be creating a "Choose Your Own Adventure" story.
(Twine does seem to encourage these, doesn't it?)
I believe their intention is to offer readers a choice between two alternate "Raw Shark Text" endings.
The outline appears comprehensive: a beginning, middle, and ending are provided.
I see that they've included a basic structure for the placement of their hyperlinks.
It's a good, clean start to the project.
In my opinion, all fanfiction is copyright infringement.
I would encourage the team to create an original story from their collective raw imagination.
Maybe consider crossing the gap between their new story and those readers who have never heard of "Raw Shark Texts".
I believe the team's division of labor will prove challenging for that whole "too many cooks in one kitchen" element.
Several people are doing similar lines of writing .
it might work out well or it might get very confusing.
I think they'll need to make sure their all on the same page (or "link", in this case).
To me, the proposal sounds like it has more in common with conceptual art than fiction, so I believe the team is going to give us something very abstract and original.
It definitely strays from the "idea of what a 'book' is", as they say.
I think they will achieve something interesting, and this perhaps is their aim.
The team's structure for their work is clear (even if I don't fully understand the details).
The outline is put together well and their summary is easy enough to understand.
There is a general worldliness to the features that they offer--grass, icebergs, birds, "everything".
The trouble with abstracts in fiction is that if they are not portrayed through concrete details they risk becoming incomprehensible.
As far as improvement, I would say the risk of writing something no one understands ought to be factored into the team's decisions and their narrative.
The greatest challenge might be in trying to be too universal.
Can they write about "everything"?
Similarly, can they reasonably expect their readers to keep adding to their story ("once the common thread is figured out")?
I would say the goal of this project is to illustrate the old cliche, "The grass is always greener on the other side."
I think the plot is very clever and well designed.
There is a cohesiveness to the narrative and a definite purpose to its course.
More, I think the parallel lives of the two main characters and the thought(s) they'll share at the ending of both stories is well-planned.
The only gaps I see are the stories' details, but these will be filled in as each author does their writing.
Having two different authors writing two different narratives that must coordinate at different points might prove difficult.
At least they're aiming for the same target--the ending--and that might make things easier.
This team is aiming to portray the lives of three people (father, mother, and daughter) as affected by the decision of whether or not to have a child.
Twine will be used to present the lives of each character as seen from their perspective.
I really like this idea!
I think using Twine to "flesh out" the lives of each character is ingenious.

Because you can't undo your choice on Twine without finishing out the story, it gives us the illusion that once we make a choice, we can't change it (although on a minor scale compared to real-life decisions).
The research/inspiration section is excellent; there are so many different sources being used to add to this story.
I really think this is a strong proposal.

I don't see any gaps, I just wonder if the interactive format will continue after the reader decides which perspective to choose, or if it will end with that and lead into three traditional short stories.
The one thing I think is important to consider is what happens after your reader makes their decision.
Will each choice lead them to another series of choices (aside from he secondary choice between POV if they initially pick "Yes"), or will it lead to separate traditional short pieces of fiction?
I only ask because I think the more interaction there is with the reader, the better, at least in terms of a futuristic interactive book.
This team is creating a story-line with an outcome that will be almost entirely established by the reader.
The reader will go through a series of choices that will determine which fictional character they are.
I think this proposal plays on a lot of well-known and well-loved characters, which will make it relevant to a lot of its readers.
It sounds like whatever the story line is will be fun and interesting, judging by the final outcome lineups!
The research section is great in explaining how and why you chose the format you chose.
I honestly don't see any gaps.
Obviously the story will have to be fleshed out a bit in terms of the details - what decisions will the reader be making, what will the actual turns be in the story, etc.
but those are all details to be worked out as it gets written.
There are a lot of possible outcomes - that means a lot of different possible combinations will have to be made into different pages.
I'm no expert in Twine, so that could be perfectly plausible, I just know on a lot of the Twines I was watching for examples there weren't quite as many possible outcomes.
Just something to consider when actually putting the plan into action!
This team is aiming to create an original story about a psychoanalyst, with the majority of the plot actually determined by the reader.
I love, LOVE the premise of this story.
It's such an interesting idea in terms of psychology.
I think psychological disorders are hugely interesting, and adding the twist just makes it even better.
The fact that it's interactive adds to its effect, because it will involve the readers in the fate of the character, giving them the power to bend her psychological well-being.
I really love every part of this, except for the Halloween aspect.
I think the constant dark rain clouds and the dark nature of the story itself will create the mood that the writers are looking for.
The Halloween setting might be overkill, unless it's somehow adding to the story's plot in a fundamental way.
I love the idea of switching back and forth between 2nd and 3rd person.
My only question would be, what is the "cue" to the reader that they are about to switch tenses?
It is a good idea to have the reader somewhat disoriented to really engage them in the story, but it has to be done really purposefully, otherwise it just creates confusion.
Will the 2nd person be in italics, for example, or will there be some other "hint" that it's in 2nd person for a reason, and not just as a slip of tense?
This team is aiming to portray a story between two friends and one's crush.
The story will use interactive formatting to draw readers in and make them feel as if they are a part of the conversation between the friends.
I think this is such a great idea, and it uses things that are relevant to its readers to further engage them in the story.
Using an e-mail format with the reply feature as a link is really clever.
The slice of life aspect of the story makes for a great interactive piece, since it doesn't necessarily have to be resolved or include anything too "deep."
I think considering that this is supposed to be a straightforward "slice of life" piece, it's really all covered in the proposal.
I don't see any gaps that need to be filled.
I might just suggest making sure the characters are somehow developed in a way that readers will really be invested in them at least somewhat, which can be difficult in e-mail format.
It can definitely be done though - there is a book series I read when I was younger where the plot is made up entirely of texts and e-mails sent between three friends.

I think the only thing that needs to be considered is how the action of the story is going to be moved forward through the e-mails without it being "obvious" - how are we going to get a good description of Trevor and still make it seem like a genuine conversation between two friends?
I'm sure it can be done and done well, it's just something to consider when writing the dialogue itself.

This project is going to give an array of voices to things which we normally don't think of as having a voice, exploring our reality in a unique way by looking at the objects around us from what sounds like a bit of a surrealist perspective.

Despite the varying objects and voices involved, the team wants the reader to be aware of the unifying voice of awareness of the story, which sounds to me maybe a bit like consciousness itself, or maybe the stream of connection from The Raw Shark Texts.
I think the second half of the proposal, of its unifying theme, is powerful and important.
This is a very 'future book'-esque concept, bringing awareness to the awareness it takes to read or interpret all of these different objects.
I'm also blown away by the great array of your influences, wow!
There are really some great works in there, and I see a direct correlation to The Illustrated Man, and I think Poe is such a pivotal and important influence on everything.
You have such a strong foundation, going off of those examples of incredible writing and concepts.
Obviously, as this is an outline only, I think the writing of the actual objects needs to be strong so this doesn't end up sounding a bit like a children's book.
Just because of the outline format, the rocks and other inanimate objects having brief voices does sound a bit surreal in a young way.
However, I totally realize that this is brief with intention and design, because this project is just for a proposal and not the actual work itself.
Your influences sound like this will be nothing like a children's book, so I think that will sort itself out as you work.
The main challenge I see here is this is a great project idea, but it sounds very labor intensive, especially making all the different voices speak in Twine in different boards.
I write a blog and I am sometimes blown away by the amount of time I've spent with just formatting and coding a single page of text, and then proofreading it.
You guys definitely have your work cut out for you!
I have a similar situation in my group, as one member isn't participating as of yet.
Hopefully if you can get all three members on board and chugging out text and inputting into Twine in a sort of pre-arranged format, you'll be able to create what you want.

My advice for this challenge would be to focus on one object, maybe, and perfect that, and gauge how long that takes before deciding how many more objects you'll be able to complete for the entire story.
This class is so accelerated, I really think time is of the essence for all of us.
But I love this idea, and this seems like a very solid project!
This team is aiming to create a chilling suspense story, and present a gripping twist at the end.
Sounds like a book I'd pick up (or click to online)...
This is an incredibly thought out proposal, specifically the story itself.
I think the concept itself is the strength, as the plot is a very inventive story.
The plot will keep the reader moving through the book, as there is suspense there.

This plot also relates to a big theme in our society today, not only through the influences that this group mentioned, but also in mystery fiction as detectives merge with the evil that they hunt, police become brutal like the bad guys that they kill, etc.
The theme here is relevant and with a twist, promises to be quite interesting.
Pivoting off of the proposal's strength, I think the storyline itself is going to be a bit difficult to build up to a quality level in a few weeks time.
I certainly have faith in the group to do it, but there is so much that needs to be filled out as this could be a lengthy novel or television show, that it will be quite a crunch.

I wonder if the concept of monsters and the concept of mental illness may be too much to present at one time, and it may be easier to simply present other people's mental illness/memories and get away from the suggestion of anything supernatural.
I think it would be awesome to incorporate the metaphor of monsters in there, if you are able, but I think it may become very complicated.
As my last response stated, I see the main problem here developing such a complicated plot in a quick time.

I'm not sure that as a reader, I would find music that helpful unless it is presented in a rhythmic way like we saw with the YH Chang videos, as I think music when reading a novel or longer work is pretty distracting.
That is just my opinion, however--I tend to be a pretty traditional reader.
I think the challenge here will be making such a complicated plot come across clearly in such a short time period.
My suggestion to complete this challenge would be focusing more on the story, as it is so strong, and less on the photos and music.
I realize that this is not a very future of the book-ish suggestion, however.
As with the first group I peer reviewed, I'm really excited for your project as it sounds very cool.

This team is aiming to illustrate the effects our choices have on us through three different narratives, from three different perspectives, of different outcomes of a pivotal argument in a couple's life--should they have child or not?

By exploring this question from several angles using different storytelling methods (point-of-view, perspective, and the technology available on Twine) this team will illustrate how our choices change our futures.
The strength here, it seems to me, is the clear divide of the storyline between the three of you.
This seems like a great way to do a group project.
I also like how two of the story arcs are drawing from such personal and unique experiences--I think each author's perspective will bring a lot to the story here.

I was actually thinking of Adam Johnson's "Trauma Plate" as the story was being described before Jeremy mentioned it in his section, so I think your influences and idea are very clear and well thought out.
As with any story where the narrative shifts, I think the hardest thing to do hear will be to maintain a unifying connection throughout the work.
I think this will also be made more difficult because each piece is being written individually.

You mentioned Cloud Atlas as an influence, and I think bringing all the stories together in some way, even if they are wildly different, whether it be through a theme or just an echo of experience, would really pull this piece together.
I think this team has done a great job of dividing their creation workload very clearly, which will really help them achieve their goals quickly.

Sort of going off of what I said above, I think coordinating the same sort of user experience between each person's narrative on Twine, as three individuals are uploading their work individually, might slow things down, but this might be unnecessary as the stories are entirely different.
This team will create an interactive narrative in which the final scenes reveal something about the reader themselves, through the options they have chosen.
The aspect that is most polished seems to be the research relating to the interactive narrative, and the concept of the interactive narrative itself.

Although this sounds quite complicated to pull off, I think the Twine format in general seems to be built exactly for this style of Choose Your Own Adventure Game and so I think this type of story will really blossom in Twine, as you'll be able to incorporate so many features you wouldn't in a hardcover book.
Definitely very future book-esque.
The gap I noticed, a bit of a pun here, is the story of the mysterious characters filling the hole.
As this is just an outline, obviously I didn't expect the whole story here but it will be interesting to see how this is executed, with the many different options and the mystery involved.

I think that games in general tend to lose the literary aspect of reading and books, and I think that the story itself, of the men and the hole, needs to not be forgotten amongst the many neat formatting options available on Twine.
There isn't much action presented here, just the mystery surrounding their identity, so I'm not sure if this is due to the outline format or it needs to be built up more.
I think this team will has chosen the most complicated Twine layout, with many multiple options and their quiz structure, out of all the projects I've reviewed.
This is great, of course, but I think this means this could be a bit of a daunting project to keep straight and format online.
As time is of the essence here, I think keeping all the multiple options and layers straight for the multiple choices will be the greatest challenge.
However, I have confidence that Twine was created for just this type of challenge, and this team will rock it.
I'm excited to see the final project.
From what I read, the team is aiming to achieve Clio Aames perspective.
In the end it all determines if Clio the reader made the right decisions.
I can see the proposal strengths are telling what story they will use which was Raw Shark Text.
They explain the novel will be told in through twines link feature and it will be a multilinear fan-fiction.
Explain more on how the sites will shape the narrative.
Probably the most difficult challenge this team will face will providing more detail of the story being told in Clio view points,
I like the idea of the project, after reading the proposal I see the team is aiming towards compare and contrast paper between the two men.
I think the strengths in the proposal are converting the men in the end to desiring each other lives in the end which shows the multilinear function of the story.
I would say comparing each of the men's lives and showing the desire for each other lives shows that the men are not appreciating what they have.

I think this proposal needs some improvement in explain in more detail the differences in the men's lives, I think it needs more information as to why the lives of each men's are appealing to each other, I think it loses the readers attention when the two men are just being compared to one another.
Also I don't see where the barista life is relevant to the lives of the two men.
You don't explain in the end what the barista is thinking.
I think the team will experience a significance challenge in merging the life of a Barista to be compared.
I think this will be the most significance challenge in achieving their goal of multilinear work of fiction.
I think the outcome of this final project will be to use the twine feature of an email link to get to the next portion of the story.
The team is aiming to achieve that the reader is able to get through the story through the email link.
I think the proposal strength in relation to the assignment is being able to accomplish an understanding of the story through the twine feature.
I think that the emails being sent in a linear timeline are the most polished and thought through.
I think that the proposal needs improvement in the characters explaining more about them will give the reader a better understanding.
I think the team will face the most significant challenge when using the twine feature of the email link.
This project will approach an epistolary story in a modern setting, using technology to more accurately represent the back-and-forth of email exchanges.
The primary strength of this proposal is that it is clean and achievable.
The use of Twine is well thought-out, and the events of the story itself is nearly complete.
Moving forward, they should have very few major hurdles to completion.
The proposal itself is sound.
The only improvements would be in finding better ways to utilize Twine beyond simply adding .gifs.
I would also like to see some theme within the story itself that is related to the course.
What makes THIS story part of our class, beyond the way it is being written?
